title: 114_hr3442
content: The Act titled "Debt Management and Fiscal Responsibility Act of 2015" requires the Secretary of the Treasury to report to Congress before reaching the debt limit. The "Debt Management and Fiscal Responsibility Act of 2015" mandates the Secretary of the Treasury to report to Congress 60-21 days before the public debt hits the limit. The report must include historical debt levels. The Secretary is required to submit a debt report in an appearance to Congress, including historical debt levels, current debt amount, future projections, federal revenue levels, future debt drivers, and how the US will meet debt obligations if the debt limit is raised. The Secretary must report to Congress on historical debt levels, current debt amount, future projections, federal revenue levels, future debt drivers, meeting debt obligations if the debt limit is raised, and reduction measures if the debt limit is not raised. The President may recommend a balanced budget amendment to control future debt accumulation. Detailed proposals for reducing public debt in the short, medium, and long term must be provided. Detailed proposals for reducing public debt in the short, medium, and long term, including adjustments to the debt-to-GDP ratio, and projections for major entitlement programs like Social Security, Medicare, and Medicaid, must be included. The curr_chunk discusses the President's plan to disclose reduction measures used to avoid defaulting on government obligations when the debt limit is reached. This includes measures currently in use and those not in use. The curr_chunk outlines the reduction measures being used by the Secretary to avoid defaulting on government obligations, including the total dollar amount used and estimated remaining amount for each measure. It also includes the date when all reduction measures will be exhausted, leading to government default. The Secretary will provide details on the remaining available funds, the date when all reduction measures will be exhausted, any extraordinary measures planned to fund government obligations, and the Administration's technological capability to pay only principal. The Secretary will provide details on available funds, the date when reduction measures will be exhausted, extraordinary measures to fund government obligations, and the Administration's capability to pay only principal and interest on the national debt. A progress report on implementing the President's proposals will also be included. The Secretary of the Treasury will publish a detailed progress report on the President's proposals, with the condition that it will only be submitted if the Secretary has appeared at least once during a President's term. Additionally, a webpage will be created to provide public access to information, including the debt report and detailed explanations. The Department of the Treasury will have a webpage with information on debt reports, detailed explanations, progress reports, and other relevant information for public access. The term 'reduction measures' is defined as directing or approving debt issuance. The term 'reduction measures' includes directing or approving debt issuance, suspending investments in various funds, and selling securities. The reduction measures include suspending investments in the stabilization fund, Civil Service Retirement and Disability Fund, and Postal Service Retiree Health Benefits Fund, as well as selling securities before maturity and other measures as determined by the Secretary. The House of Representatives passed a report before reaching the debt limit on February 11, 2016. Attest: KAREN L. HAAS, Clerk.
